an11.6:1.1: “Mendicants, any mendicant who abuses and insults their spiritual companions, speaking ill of the noble ones, will, without a doubt, fall into one or other of these eleven disasters.
an11.6:2.3: What they have achieved falls away.
an11.6:2.4: They don’t refine their good qualities.
an11.6:2.6: Or they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.
an11.6:2.7: Or they commit a corrupt offense.
an11.6:2.8: Or they resign the training and return to a lesser life.
an11.6:2.9: Or they contract a severe illness.
an11.6:2.10: Or they go mad and lose their mind.
an11.6:2.11: They feel lost when they die.
an11.6:2.12: And when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an11.6:2.13: Any mendicant who abuses and insults their spiritual companions, speaking ill of the noble ones, will, without a doubt, fall into one or other of these eleven disasters.
an11.6:3.1: Any mendicant who does not abuse and insult their spiritual companions, speaking ill of the noble ones, will, without a doubt, not fall into one or other of these eleven disasters.
an11.6:4.3: What they have achieved falls away.
an11.6:4.4: They don’t refine their good qualities.
an11.6:4.6: Or they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.
an11.6:4.7: Or they commit one of the corrupt offenses.
an11.6:4.8: Or they resign the training and return to a lesser life.
an11.6:4.9: Or they contract a severe illness.
an11.6:4.10: Or they go mad and lose their mind.
an11.6:4.11: They feel lost when they die.
an11.6:4.12: And when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an11.6:4.13: Any mendicant who does not abuse and insult their spiritual companions, speaking ill of the noble ones, will, without a doubt, not fall into one or other of these eleven disasters.”
